data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Trust recognises the importance of ensuring that all members of staff work in an environment where they feel supported and valued. However, the Trust also recognises that there are times when a member of staff may be unhappy with some aspect of their working environment.

All Trust members of staff, volunteers, bank workers, apprentice, contractors and medical staff, staff seconded /work for the Trust is some other capacity i.e. honorary staff who have a legitimate work-related complaint have the right to raise a formal complaint or “grievance” under this policy. Any complaints concerning an agency worker should be referred to the employing Agency for them to follow their own procedures in relation to their worker.

However, the working pattern and location of the parties concerned will be considered to ensure that all hearings are held on normal working days for all parties concerned, wherever practicable. Any members of staff who raise a legitimate grievance will not be treated unfavourably at any time as a result of raising the grievance.

Wherever possible, members of staff are encouraged to resolve grievances informally. This procedure therefore should only be used where it is not possible to resolve an issue informally, in discussions with the staff members line manager.
Scope

This document sets out the policy and procedure for members of staff who believe that they have been unfairly treated and wish to seek redress for an action which the Trust has taken or is contemplating taking in relation to any working practice in respect of their employment.
This procedure aims to ensure that all grievances, both individual and collective, are resolved quickly, fairly and consistently.
Issues that may cause grievances include:
Dissatisfaction with terms and conditions of employment;
Health & safety matters;
Working practices or the working environment;
Discrimination;
How policies and procedures have been interpreted.
This procedure does not apply to settling grievances relating to:
Matters for which it has been agreed that specific national procedures will apply;
Matters which have been consulted upon and implemented via the Trust Organisational Change Policy (MSBPO-18009);
Dismissals or warnings issued under any formal process;
Bullying or harassment (see Bullying & Harassment at Work Policy);

Whistleblowing (see Whistleblowing Policy), except where any member of staff is directly affected by the matter in question, or where they feel they have been victimised for an act of whistleblowing, then they may raise the matter under this procedure;
Banding decisions reached using the Trust's agreed Job Evaluation process;
Matters over which the Trust has no control, e.g. tax, National Insurance
Private grievances between members of staff which are not related to the working environment.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Managers
Managers are required to develop a working environment in which views can be expressed openly and listened to constructively and fairly, in order that formal grievances are avoided
Managers should attempt to resolve grievances informally wherever possible

Managers are advised to take care in identifying a potential grievance. They should treat written requests, strongly worded correspondence, including a resignation letter or exit interview as a potential grievance. In circumstances where  such  correspondence  is  received,  they  will  clarify  with  the correspondent whether or not such material is to be treated as a grievance, and begin the grievance procedure as necessary
Managers will inform the Employee Relations Team whenever a potential grievance is considered or an actual grievance is submitted
All Staff
Staff have a responsibility to engage with communication methods and to ensure they  discuss with their manager issues about which they feel dissatisfied
Staff have a responsibility for maintaining a professional boundary, by ensuring their own behaviour does not contravene employment legislation or good employment practice
Staff and managers should refer to their professional code of conduct, the NHS Constitution, the NHS ‘Code of Conduct for NHS Managers' and relevant policies for further guidance
Employee Relations
The Director of Organisational Development and Workforce has delegated responsibility from the Board to ensure this Policy and associated procedure is properly implemented and monitored
The Employee Relations Team has a responsibility to ensure that the Policy and Procedure is followed, fairly and consistently
An Employee Relations representative will attend all formal stages of the procedure, and will advise the manager that a note-taker should be present to take notes
Staff Side Representatives
Provide informed advice and support to union members who approach them for help in relation to raising a concern.
Encourage and support staff to work with the Trust to resolve concerns constructively and at the earliest possible stage to avoid them escalating into more serious issues.

The Staff Side representative should as much as possible make themselves available on the chosen date of the hearing. If the date is not convenient (for a good reason), an alternative date may be arranged as long as it ideally falls within 5 working days of the original date.
The right to be accompanied does not extend to legal representatives, or friends and relations not employed by the Trust.
The Staff Side representative will be permitted to address the meeting to put and sum up the member of staff case.
The Staff Side representative will be permitted to have a discussion with the member of staff during the meeting.
The Staff Side representative does not have the right to answer any questions on the member of staffs behalf, address the meeting without the
member of staffs permission or prevent the staff member from participating in the process.
Procedure

For the purposes of this procedure a grievance will be interpreted as an issue which has been placed in writing in accordance with this process to confirm the fact that the members of staff is aggrieved. In general, these issues will tend to be complaints by a staff member against an action that a fellow member of staff or the Trust itself has taken or is contemplating taking in relation to the member of staff. This may include such matters as:
Duties and Responsibilities;
Conditions of employment;
Working practices;
Discrimination.

This list is not exhaustive, as there are other potential sources of a grievance. For staff concerns about health care matters and complaints in relation to bullying and harassment issues separate procedures apply, but in such cases raising a formal grievance would be the last step if all other efforts fail and there is no separate procedure.

Where a complaint or grievance relates to the member of staffs immediate Line Manager, the Grievance Procedure can be commenced by approaching the Employee Relations team in confidence or the appropriate next level alternative manager.
The procedure for resolving a grievance must follow the sequence detailed below.
(Refer to Appendix 4) Stage 1 - Informal

Staff must raise their concerns about an issue in which they are directly involved primarily with their Line Manager. Should such issues not be satisfactorily resolved, this informal stage of the Grievance Procedure must be implemented as an escalation to formality. The grievance, should in the first instance be raised in writing on the Grievance Form (refer to Appendix

1) to their immediate Line Manger by giving detail of the reason for the grievance, giving an explanation of its basis, what endeavours have taken place and what resolution is sought. Where a member of staff has difficulty expressing them self in writing, they should be encouraged to seek help from a colleague, staff representative or Employee Relations Advisor. Receipt of the grievance will be acknowledged within 7 calendar days by the Line Manager, with the staff member being sent a copy of the Grievance Procedure, for their information.

A meeting will take place with the relevant manager to discuss the grievance within 7 calendar days of the Stage 1 grievance being raised. The Line Manager will respond to the grievance in writing within 7 calendar days of the meeting. The Line Manager will also inform the member of staff of their right
to raise their grievance at Stage 2, should they feel that their issue is still unresolved.

In many instances, an informal discussion with the staff member's manager can result in an immediate solution, and may make it unnecessary to use the formal process. However, where this is not possible the following procedure will apply.
Stage 2 - Formal

If the matter is not resolved at Stage 1, the member of staff will refer it in writing on a Stage 2 Grievance Form (refer to Appendix 2), within 7 calendar days of receipt of the written outcome of Stage  to the next level of management. The details must include the Stage 1 Grievance Form and clearly set out the grounds for the complaint, the activity and outcome from Stage 1 and the reasons for the dissatisfaction with the Stage 1 response.
A meeting will take place, with the relevant manager and a member of the Employee Relations Team within 7 calendar days of the request being raised at this stage, to discuss the formal grievance.

At this point the manager has the discretion to commission a full investigation in line with the Workforce Investigations Policy. With the support of the Employee Relations Advisor, the decision will be made whether any investigation remains within the Division/Directorate or whether an investigating officer from another Division/Directorate is appointed.
Should an investigation be commissioned, the member of staff will receive written confirmation that an Investigation will take place, which the Investigating Officer is, timescales, etc.

Should there not be the necessity for an Investigation, following the meeting, the manager will respond to the Stage  grievance in writing within 14 calendar days of the meeting. The Stage 2 Manager will also inform the member of staff of their right to raise their grievance at Stage 3, should they feel that their issue is still unresolved.
Stage 3 - Final

If the matter is not resolved at stage 2, the member of staff, will refer the grievance in writing on a Stage 3 Grievance Form (refer to Appendix 3), within 7 calendar days to the next level of management as appropriate. The details will be stated in writing, clearly setting out the grounds for the complaint, the reasons for the dissatisfaction with the Stage 2 response. All supporting documentation from Stages 1 and 2 should be submitted

A meeting will take place, with the relevant Associate Director and Employee Relations Advisor within 14 calendar days of the request being raised at this stage, wherever practicable, to discuss the grievance. Following the meeting the associate director will respond to the grievance in writing within 14 calendar days of the meeting. The decision of the associate director is the final stage of the procedure.
In carrying out this procedure it is essential that each stage is followed correctly and no individual becomes involved until the appropriate stage of the procedure.
Format of Meetings

It is the Trust's intention that all grievance meetings should be held on a normal working day, this will vary depending on the type of location and work pattern. The member of staff will liaise with their Representative and Employee Relations Advisor to coordinate dates. The arrangements for the meeting will be confirmed by the appropriate Manager. Therefore the above timescales may be extended if a member of staff is off shift/on leave/sick. And the reasons for this delay will be communicated in writing to the staff member.

If the member of staff is unable to attend, for unforeseen reasons, dependent upon circumstances, rearrangement may be possible; ordinarily and subject to individual circumstances, any meetings held in accordance with this policy will not be rearranged on more than one occasion.

The details of the meeting, i.e. time, date and venue, will, wherever possible, be confirmed with the staff member beforehand. If the member of staff's chosen representative is unavailable at the original time, the staff member is required to make an alternative arrangement, within seven calendar days of the original. If so, the meeting will be held at the new time and date. If the member of staff is unable to do this, then the meeting may go ahead without the chosen companion, after the 7 calendar days. However the member of staff must take all reasonable steps to attend the meeting.
The member of staff will be informed, in writing of the details of the meeting.

The meeting will consist of the staff member, their representative, Employee Relations Advisor and the appropriate Manager as the Chair. At the meeting, the Chair will introduce those present, and explain their roles. The rest of the meeting will be conducted in such a way that allows both parties to explain their cases fully.

Only in exceptional circumstances, for example, where a party believes that it may be exposed to a significant threat, such as violent, abusive, intimidating behaviour, or where a step cannot be complied within a reasonable period of time, such as long term illness, may a meeting be postponed.

Written records will be kept detailing the nature of the grievance; copy of the written grievance; member of staff's response; action taken; reason why the action was taken; whether or not there was an appeal and if so, the outcome; and subsequent developments.
Representation
A staff member may wish to have their staff representative to accompany them. This person can be either a fellow member of staff or recognised Trade Union Representative.

The chosen companion has a statutory right to address the meeting and to confer with the member of staff, but no statutory right to answer questions on the staff members behalf. They will also be permitted reasonable time to confer privately with the member of staff and to ask questions on their behalf.
It is the member of staff's responsibility to appoint a representative, provide that representative with all relevant information pertaining to the grievance.

Collective Grievances  Where this is to be the case, all staff taking part in the grievance must sign their consent to the Trust requesting that a Staff Side Member or appropriately appointed spokesperson is used. The chosen Staff Side Member or spokesperson will then be invited to follow the procedure as set out above.
Status Quo

In the case of a dispute the status quo clause shall only apply if staff are affected with an imminent change that excludes the possibility of the grievance procedure being followed prior to the change and is lodged by an accredited staff representative.

There can be no status quo for changes that have been properly consulted upon and implemented via the Trust Organisational Change Policy. Any issues in this regard must be raised by accredited staff representatives. These concerns will be heard by the Director of Workforce and the Staff Side Chair who will determine whether the status quo shall apply or not. If they cannot agree then the matter will be referred to the Chief Executive whose decision will be final
The definition of ‘status quo' is the existing arrangements in operation immediately prior to the subject of the grievance being made.
No Disruption to Work

It is essential to the proper working of this procedure that any member of staff raising a grievance should continue to work normally whilst the procedure is followed. There should be no disruption to work on the part of the member of staff / staff representative during the course of this process. Where members of staff are unhappy with management decisions, they shall continue to do their work as instructed, under protest if necessary while their grievance(s) is being processed. The Trust reserves the right to remove people from their work area should it be deemed necessary. This action should only be undertaken with the full involvement of the Employee Relations team.
Post Termination Grievances

Wherever possible a grievance should be raised and dealt with before a member of staff leaves the employment of the Trust. However, where this is not possible, or where a grievance is received from an ex-employee, a two- step modified procedure will be implemented as follows:
The ex-employee must set out their grievance in writing; and

The relevant manager will set out their written response on behalf of the Trust to the ex-employee within a reasonable timescale which will normally be within 1 calendar month following receipt of the written grievance.

Grievances will only normally be accepted from ex-employees where they have been raised within 3 months following the matter that prompted the complaint. In any event this should be no later than three calendar months after leaving the employment of the Trust. Grievances should be made as soon as possible, to enable the Trust to investigate and respond to in a timely manner.
Grievances Which Fall Outside This Procedure

Where a complaint falls within one of these areas staff should make use of the relevant alternative Trust procedures; for example issues such as Harassment or Bullying, or Whistleblowing, which may amount to a protected disclosure under the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998, or relating to a disciplinary decision.
Time Limits

A grievance may be raised at any point within  months of the action happening over which the individual wishes to raise a grievance. Similarly, any grievance, which was heard in excess of 3 months previously, will be deemed to be closed and resolved after the completion of 3 months from the date of the final grievance meeting outcome confirmation.
Protection against Unfair Treatment or Reprisals

Members of staff, and staff representatives, have the right not to suffer detriment or reprisals as recourse for choosing to exercise their grievance entitlement or for representing/ accompanying someone whom has chosen to exercise their grievance entitlement
Inappropriate Grievances

Should it become apparent to the relevant manager during the Grievance process that inappropriate allegations have been made, or that the grievance procedure itself has been used to provoke or intimidate other staff members, the Trust does have the right to establish the facts and following full investigation has the right to implement its Disciplinary Procedure as appropriate.
Training Requirements
Investigating Officers must meet at least one of the following criteria in order to undertake investigations under this policy:
Have attended appropriate investigation training either provided by the Trust or externally;
Have previous experience in undertaking formal investigations;
Be approved by a member of the HR Operations team as competent to undertake investigations through previous experience or training, skill or knowledge;
Be mentored and coached by a member of the HR Operations team or a trained investigator during the investigation to ensure that they have access to specialist advice and support;
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the Employee Relations departments across the Trust and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust Intranets. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations team.
References
This policy should be read in accordance with the following Trust procedures:
Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998
Equality Impact Assessment

The Trust is committed to a policy of equality in all its employment practices and strives to eliminate all unfair discrimination, harassment, bullying and victimisation. Equality of opportunity is a high priority within the Trust and it will not unlawfully, unfairly or unreasonably discriminate or treat individuals less favourably on the grounds of gender, marital status, sexual orientation, religion or belief, disability, age, race, nationality or ethnic origin.
In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used
to assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was
found to be compliant with this assessment. (Refer to Appendix 5)
Sources of Support (Internal and External)
Internal
Guidance for Managers

There are a number of links between this policy and the Trust's appraisal framework, which sets out the behaviours that the Trust defines as putting patients first and those which are counter-productive to achieving the Trust's goals. Managers dealing with potentially inappropriate behaviours may wish to use the appraisal framework and the Trust Values as a tool to help in the management of behaviours.
Occupational Health

Occupational Health provides a confidential counselling service for those members of staff who have a problem that is affecting their work and personal life. In certain circumstances where more specialised counselling is required, they will recommend an agency for the member of staff to contact direct. Staff may either be referred to Occupational Health by their manager (with consent) or may refer themselves confidentially. Further information is available on the Intranet or staff can contact Occupational Health by telephone through the hospital switchboard.
Equality and Diversity Manager

In addition to leading the Equality and Diversity agenda for the Trust, the Equality and Diversity Manager provides a confidential service for staff to address issues relating to discrimination that they may experience. The E&D manager can be contacted through Human Resources.
Patient experience
Open forum for staff to attend when they require help with issues.
Forum for developing and agreeing best practice evidence for Essence of Care privacy and dignity standard.
Staff Representatives

The Trust recognises a number of trades unions and professional bodies, who can be valuable sources of advice and support. Staff are advised to contact either their Trade Union Steward, whose contact details should be on the Staff Side notice boards around the Trust, the Staff Side Office, or the Head Office of their Union, who will be able to put them in touch with an appropriate local representative.
Freedom to Speak up Guardian

The Guardian Service is an independent and confidential service established to support NHS staff at all levels and in all roles. The role of a Guardian supports the individual to rationalise their concerns to a point where they can determine for themselves the appropriate course of further action with or without ongoing Guardian support. The Freedom to Speak Up Guardian is Patricia Simmons, hotline available 24/7 on 0333577 5799
Security Team

The security team work with the NHS Security Management Service (NHS SMS) to protect NHS staff and patients. If you experience physical assault or verbal abuse from another member of staff or if you feel concerned for your personal safety, you can contact the security team who are based on the main hospital site 24 hours per day, 7 days a week, or contact the security management team who will be able to advise and support you in any way deemed necessary.
The team can be contacted as follows: Head of Security:
Mid Essex Hospital ext. 6367;
Basildon Hospital ext. 3312;
Southend Hospital ext. 5413.
Dignity and Respect Action Group (DRAG):
The Dignity and Respect Action Group (DRAG) provides a forum for staff and patients to address issues of dignity and respect. Aims of the group are:
Forum to support champions of Dignity & Respect;
Forum for presentation and discussion of ideas problems and issues;
Forum to write action plans to deliver a better patient experience.
External
ACAS – the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service
ACAS is an independent organisation which aims to improve organisations and working life through better employment relations.

They promote best practice in the workplace through easily accessible advice and services. They provide free impartial advice to individuals via their website: www.acas.org.uk and telephone helpline - 03001231100. The Helpline provides clear, confidential, independent and impartial advice to assist the caller in resolving issues in the workplace.
CIC- Employee Assistance Service

Members of staff throughout the Trust can use the Employee Assistance Service provided by CiC. It is available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year and offers independent, free and confidential advice on a variety of issues including Debt Management, Counselling & Emotional Support, Family problems, Legal and Tax Advice.

The FREEPHONE telephone number is   and CIC also provides an online area where staff can create a secure personal account which enables them to access a variety of information resources including useful tips, facts and help sheets, podcasts and secure, confidential email counselling.
Victim Support

In rare cases e.g. if an assault has occurred, a grievance may overlap with a police investigation. Where members of staff are the victims of a crime, they have the option of contacting Victim Support, which is an independent charity which helps people to cope with the effects of crime. They provide free and confidential support and information to help victims of crime to deal with their experience.
Victim support has a website http://www.victimsupport.org.uk/ and a national telephone support line - 0845
